case_name: Peoples Union for Democratic Rights vs. Union of India
facts: The case involved the employment of children below 14 years of age in hazardous construction work at the site of the Supreme Court building. The petitioners challenged the employment of these children, arguing it violated constitutional provisions and child labour laws.
legal_issues: Whether employment of children below 14 years in hazardous occupations violates Article 24 of the Constitution.
Whether constitutional provisions protecting children override any lack of specific legislation.
judgment: The Supreme Court held that Article 24 of the Constitution prohibits employment of children in hazardous occupations and processes. The Court emphasized that the constitutional prohibition is absolute and not dependent on the existence of specific legislation. The employment of children in construction work was declared illegal and unconstitutional.
legal_reasoning: The Court interpreted Article 24 as a fundamental safeguard for children’s health and development, emphasizing the State’s duty to protect children from exploitation in hazardous work environments. The judgment reinforced that constitutional protections prevail over any administrative lapses or legislative gaps.
legal_principle: Article 24 of the Constitution prohibits employment of children below 14 years in hazardous occupations and processes.
relevant_sections: Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (applicable provisions)

case_name: Francis Coralie Mullin vs. Union Territory of Delhi
facts: The petitioner challenged the conditions of prisoners including juveniles, arguing that their right to life and dignity under Article 21 was being violated by poor living conditions and forced labour.
legal_issues: Whether the right to life under Article 21 includes the right to live with human dignity, including protection of health and strength.
Whether child labour and exploitation violate fundamental rights.
judgment: The Supreme Court expanded the interpretation of Article 21 to include the right to live with human dignity and protection of health and strength of workers, including children. The Court held that children have a right to grow in a healthy environment and receive education, and any exploitation or abuse violates their fundamental rights.
legal_reasoning: The Court reasoned that the right to life is not merely survival but includes the right to a life of dignity, health, and education. This interpretation extends to protect children from labour exploitation and ensures their holistic development.
legal_principle: Article 21 encompasses the right to health, education, and protection from exploitation, especially for children.

case_name: Laborers Working on Salal vs. State of Jammu and Kashmir
court: High Court of Jammu and Kashmir
facts: The case concerned the employment of children under 14 years by contractors and sub-contractors in factories and construction sites in Jammu and Kashmir. The petitioners sought enforcement of child labour laws prohibiting such employment.
legal_issues: Whether contractors and sub-contractors can employ children below 14 years in factories.
Extent of enforcement and penalties for violation of child labour laws.
judgment: The High Court ruled that no child below 14 years shall be employed by any contractor or sub-contractor in factories or hazardous occupations. The Court directed immediate removal of such children and mandated reporting of violations to appropriate authorities.
legal_reasoning: The Court emphasized strict enforcement of child labour prohibitions to protect children’s health and development. It underscored the responsibility of contractors and government authorities to prevent exploitation.
legal_principle: Strict prohibition on employment of children under 14 years in factories and hazardous work, with accountability for contractors.
relevant_sections: Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 Section 3

case_name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha v. Union of India and others
facts: The petition challenged the existence of bonded labour, including children, in various industries and agricultural sectors. It sought directions for the release and rehabilitation of bonded labourers.
legal_issues: Whether bonded labour violates fundamental rights under the Constitution.
State’s obligation to eradicate bonded labour and rehabilitate victims.
judgment: The Supreme Court held that bonded labour is a violation of Article 23 (prohibition of trafficking and forced labour) and Article 21 (right to life and liberty). The Court mandated the State governments to acknowledge bonded labour’s existence and take effective steps for its eradication and rehabilitation of victims.
legal_reasoning: The Court emphasized that bonded labour is a form of exploitation incompatible with constitutional values. It underscored the proactive role of the State in protecting vulnerable populations, especially children.
legal_principle: Eradication of bonded labour is a constitutional obligation under Articles 23 and 21.

case_name: Sheela Barse v. Union of India
facts: The petitioner highlighted the plight of children in prisons and juvenile homes, urging the Court to protect their rights and ensure their welfare and development.
legal_issues: Judicial responsibility to protect child rights.
Ensuring education and rehabilitation for children in custody.
judgment: The Supreme Court recognized the child as a state’s blessing and emphasized the judiciary’s role in ensuring laws protecting children are implemented effectively. The Court called for expansion and enforcement of laws to safeguard children’s rights and development.
legal_reasoning: The Court stressed the importance of judicial activism in child protection and the need for continuous monitoring and improvement of child welfare systems.
legal_principle: Judiciary has a proactive role in child rights protection and law enforcement.
relevant_sections: Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000

case_name: TMA Pai Foundation v. Union of India
facts: The case dealt with the right to education and the duties of parents and the State in ensuring free and compulsory education for children under 14 years.
legal_issues: Whether education is a fundamental right under the Constitution.
Parental and State obligations to prevent child labour through education.
judgment: The Supreme Court recognized education as a fundamental right essential for child development. It held that parents and guardians have a fundamental duty to provide education to children, which is key to preventing child labour. The judgment paved the way for the enactment of the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009.
legal_reasoning: The Court reasoned that education empowers children and prevents their exploitation in labour. It emphasized the State’s role in providing infrastructure and enforcing compulsory education laws.
legal_principle: Right to education is fundamental and instrumental in child labour prevention.
relevant_sections: Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education Act, 2009

case_name: M.C. Mehta vs State of Tamil Nadu and Others
facts: The petitioner challenged the employment of children in hazardous industries in Tamil Nadu, seeking compensation and rehabilitation for affected children.
legal_issues: Violation of child labour laws in hazardous industries.
judgment: The Supreme Court ordered that employers violating child labour prohibitions pay Rs. 20,000 per child as compensation to the Child Labour Rehabilitation-cum-Welfare Fund. The Court emphasized rehabilitation and education for rescued children.
legal_reasoning: The Court highlighted the need for strict deterrence against child labour and the importance of rehabilitation and education to restore children’s rights and dignity.
legal_principle: Strict penalties and rehabilitation funds are essential to combat child labour violations.
relevant_sections: Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 Section 17

case_name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha v. Union of India and others (Carpet Industry Case)
facts: The case involved forced employment of children below 14 years in the carpet weaving industry in Uttar Pradesh. The petitioners sought directions for release, rehabilitation, and socio-economic justice for these children.
legal_issues: Forced child labour in carpet industry.
State’s responsibility for socio-economic justice and child development.
judgment: The Supreme Court held that the State has an obligation to provide socio-economic justice, including education, health, and rehabilitation facilities, to children exploited in forced labour. The Court mandated strict enforcement of child labour laws in the carpet industry.
legal_reasoning: The Court recognized forced child labour as a violation of fundamental rights and emphasized the State’s duty to ensure proper development and welfare of children.
legal_principle: State responsibility to protect children from forced labour and ensure their holistic development.
